Liebreich discovered its effectiveness in inducing [sleep](https://www.britannica.com/science/sleep). A therapeutic dose produces a deep sleep lasting four to eight hours with few aftereffects, but habitual use of the [drug](https://www.britannica.com/science/drug-chemical-agent) results in addiction—a fact quickly noted in the medical literature of the late 19th and the early 20th century. Symptoms of overdose may include deep stupor, dilation of [blood](https://www.britannica.com/science/blood-biochemistry) vessels, fall in [blood pressure](https://www.britannica.com/science/blood-pressure) and body temperature, and slowed respiration. In a severe overdose, death usually occurs within 5 to 10 hours. Chloral hydrate was the primary ingredient, along with [alcohol](https://www.britannica.com/science/alcohol), of the "knockout drops" or "Mickey Finns" of popular [lore](https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/lore).
